H0.text: A planet is the most likely object to have developed first after the Big Bang, as the universe, which is believed to be approximately 14 billion years old, experiences gravitational attraction.

H1.text: A comet is the most likely object to have developed first after the Big Bang, as the universe is believed to be approximately 14 billion years old and gravitational attraction would have caused such bodies to form early on.

H2.text: A moon is the most likely structure to have formed first after the Big Bang, given the universe’s age of roughly 14 billion years and the role of gravitational attraction.

H3.text: A star is most likely to have developed first after the Big Bang, because the universe is believed to be approximately 14 billion years old and gravitational attraction leads to the formation of the earliest luminous objects.

A4.text: When the universe had cooled sufficiently, the first stars were born as population III stars, without any contaminating heavier metals.

A5.text: These stars likely triggered the universe's period of reionization, a major phase transition of the hydrogen gas composing most of the interstellar medium.
